issue.title: [Feature] Add schedule deployment of what is on main
issue.body:
**Describe the solution you'd like**
Every day, multiple times a day a new deployment should be generated to load the latest activity.

Will need to make sure some e2e tests are still ran, a long with lighthouse tests.

Possibly look into how to handle rollbacks as well?

comment.body: Going to pick this up, but it will be a manual job.

commits.message: chore: continued work on seconds-tracker and rigging up logic
chore: start work on tracker config settings
chore: started working on seconds tracker

issue.title: [Chore] Todo list
issue.body:
**What needs to be done**

This issue will be used to keep track of the general todos to get this project up and running.

- add an "in-memory" or "basic" tracker that saves no information no-where. This will be the simplest and more or less keep track of which types of files are tracked and how. 
- determine what is the best format for configuration for keeping track of how files are tracked. 


The basic idea is since we are saving this data locally, the data should be saved in a small of a footprint as possible, with flexibility to upgrade to more complex forms later if the user chooses to do so.

My original idea is something like the format of:
```
trackers: [
  {
    id: 'my-source-files',
    type: 'basic-memory',
    blob: '**/*.ts'
  },
  {
    id: 'my-test-files',
    type: 'basic-memory',
    blob: '**/*.spec.ts'
  }
]
```

This would keep track of two timers (in memory for the in-memory tracker):
```bash
{
  'my-source-files': 1234,
  'my-test-files': 1234
}
```

Either globally or within the codebase. This should be simple enough to understand and provide a way to expand on this later. 

However practically this could be extended more dramatically with different types of trackers.

Displaying this information could be done via a new command, or another configuration setting for displaying it on the bottom of the page. 


- Add other helper commands, such as clearing previous trackers.

- Determine class interface for "trackers". 
  - register - one-time setup when the whole extension is added to vscode. Maybe creates base files? Might not be needed?
  - enabled - setup when extension is enabled via command, called when extension is enabled/started
  - disabled - teardown when extension is disabled via command, called when extension is enabled
  - clear - called via command to clear the given tracker information, should handle the `id` of the tracker to identify different ones. 



Its possible saving more events, and thus more data-points might be a nice to have future feature, but I think a "basic-memory", "basic-global" and "basic-workspace" are good starting points to keep track of just how much time is spent in a file that matches the given blob.

comment.body:
**update**

After thinking about it I believe the right course is to keep track of the following:
- location (memory, globally, workspace)
- file - the file "glob" is used to determine what file your in.
- data - time, by-hour, by-day
  - time is saved in seconds
  - by-hour and by-day is saved in an array


need to think of common uses-cases and will report back.

issue.body:
**What needs to be done**

This issue will be used to keep track of the general todos to get this project up and running.

- add an "in-memory" or "basic" tracker that saves no information no-where. This will be the simplest and more or less keep track of which types of files are tracked and how.

The basic idea is since we are saving this data locally, the data should be saved in a small of a footprint as possible, with flexibility to upgrade to more complex forms later if the user chooses to do so.


```bash
{
```

  - enabled - setup when extension is enabled via command, called when extension is enabled/started

commits.message: fix: compile issue within forem-api including tools

issue.title: [Blog] Past technologies used for previous versions of portfolio

labels.name: blog
labels.description: An issue that represents a topic to write a blog post about

issue.body: This portfolio is actually the 3rd generation, each of which used a different technology stack, but the same infrastructure.

comment.body:
This seems like a sensible blog post to write.

---

The 2 previous generations can be found here:
- https://github.com/bradtaniguchi/bradtaniguchi.github.io-legacy
  - written in angularjs + gulp + material 
  - basic implementation with bad SEO and optimization.
- https://github.com/bradtaniguchi/bradtaniguchi.github.io-legacy-2
  - written in Angular + scully + nx + primercss/material
  - A more serious professional level portfolio, most of which is what this version is based on
  - scully development experiment was a **massive pain**
  - used a similar underlying tooling, as both are based on nx



Can also go into the improvements expected with this new version.
